Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

As Sarah worked on computer problems, she would ask questions. She wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys" of computer security, and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Sarah began to stand out. She learned about firewalls, passwords, and encryption. She became known for her knowledge and began to work with teams made up of experts. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and they increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed. Sarah's work in computer security helped protect the data of people all over the world. She made a big difference.

In the beginning, the students were careless with passwords. They would write them down and leave them in plain sight. They didn't understand why passwords were important, and they certainly didn't know how to use them securely. But when they learned about computer security, they began to change their behavior. They started using strong passwords and keeping them secret. They also learned how to use encryption to protect their online information. As they learned, they began to take their security more seriously.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 100 words. 

Computer security helps protect our digital information from unwanted intruders. Just like a safe has a lock, computers and phones have special codes that only the right people can open. A good computer security system includes strong passwords, firewalls, and antivirus programs. Imagine you're a detective trying to catch a thief. You would want to gather clues and piece together the evidence to catch the bad guy. Similarly, computer security systems work by gathering clues and blocking any suspicious activity to keep our digital information safe. Here is a short paragraph about computer security:
"Computer security is very important. Like Ruth gathering grain from the fields, computer users must be careful to protect their information from people who might try to take it. When you're online, hackers might try to sneak into your computer to steal your passwords or private messages. It's like someone following Ruth and trying to take her grain! To stay safe, you should use strong passwords, be careful what websites you visit, and keep your computer up to date with the latest security updates. This way, you can protect your information like Ruth protected her grain."

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'computer security' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 100 words. "Computer security" is the practice of protecting a computer or network from unauthorized access, use, or damage. Here's an attempt:

As you surfed the internet, you may have heard of hackers. They try to get into computers and steal information. That's why computer security is important. It's like locking your door at home to keep strangers out. When you're online, you need to use strong passwords and keep your software up to date. You should also be careful about the websites you visit and the emails you open. By following these simple rules, you can help keep your computer safe from hackers and keep your information secure. Your parents and teachers can help you learn more.

Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.
